sen.j: オオゲツヒメ（オホゲツヒメ、大宜都比売、大気都比売神、大宜津比売神）は、日本神話に登場する神。
sen.e: Oogetsuhime (Ohogetsuhime) is a deity who appears in the Japanese Mythology.
Ogetsuhime (Ohogetsuhime) is a deity who appears in the Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 名前の「オオ」は「多」の意味、「ケ」は食物の意で、穀物や食物の神である。
sen.e: "Oo" and "ke" of her name mean "a lot of" and "food" respectively and she is a deity of grain and food.
The "O" and "ge" in her name mean "a lot of" and "food" respectively, and she is a deity of grain and food.

sen.j: 古事記においては、国産みにおいて伊予之二名島（四国）の中の阿波国の名前として初めて表れる。
sen.e: Her name firstly appears in Kojiki (The Record of Ancient Matters) as the name of Awa Province in Iyononinashima (Shikoku) in connection with the story of kuniumi (the birth of Japan).

sen.e: According to the followin description of Kojiki concerning kamiumi (the birth of deities), she was born between Izanagi and Izanami.

sen.e: Concerning the reason why the original name of Awa Province was Otsugehime, it is generally explained that it was merely a pun of hindsight using Awa and a name of grain "awa (millet)".

sen.j: 高天原を追放されたスサノオは、空腹を覚えてオオゲツヒメに食物を求め、オオゲツヒメはおもむろに様々な食物をスサノオに与えた。
sen.e: After being exiled from Takamanohara, Susanoo felt hungry and asked Ogetsuhime for food and she slowly gave Susanoo various kinds of food.
After being exiled from Takamanohara, Susano felt hungry and asked Ogetsuhime for food, and Ogetsuhime slowly gave Susano various kinds of food.

sen.j: それを不審に思ったスサノオが食事の用意をするオオゲツヒメの様子を覗いてみると、オオゲツヒメは鼻や口、尻から食材を取り出し、それを調理していた。
sen.e: Susanoo, who was suspicious of her behavior, watched how Ogetsuhime was preparing food and found that Ogetsuhime was pulling foodstuffs out of her nose, mouth and anus and was cooking them.

sen.j: スサノオは、そんな汚い物を食べさせていたのかと怒り、オオゲツヒメを斬り殺してしまった。
sen.e: Susanoo became angry for being fed such dirty food and killed her with a sword.
Susano became angry for being fed such dirty food and killed Ogetsuhime with a sword.

sen.j: すると、オオゲツヒメの頭からカイコが生まれ、目からイネが生まれ、耳から粟が生まれ、鼻から小豆が生まれ、陰部からムギが生まれ、尻からダイズが生まれた。
sen.e: Then, silkworms were born from Ogetsuhime's head, rice plants were born from her eyes, millet was born from her ears, azuki beans were born from her nose, barley was born from her genitals and beans were born from her anus.

sen.j: オオゲツヒメは古事記において五穀や養蚕の起源として書かれているが、日本書紀では同様の話がツクヨミがウケモチを斬り殺す話として出てくる。
sen.e: While Ogetsuhime was described in Kojiki as the origin of grain or silkworm breeding, a similar anecdote in which Tsukuyomi killed Ukemochi with a sword appears in "Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)".

sen.j: なお、ここでオオゲツヒメはスサノオに殺されている筈だが、後に大年神の系譜においてハヤマトの妻として八神を生んだとの記述がある。
sen.e: Further, although Ogetsuhime must have been killed by Susano in this incident, the lineage of Otoshi no kami (the guardian deity of grain), which was compiled later, describes that she gave birth to eight deities as a wife of Hayamato.

sen.j: 穀物・養蚕の神として信仰されるが、後に同じ穀物の神である稲荷神と混同されるようになり、ウカノミタマの代わりに稲荷社に祀られていることがある。
sen.e: While she has been worshipped as a deity of grain/silkworm breeding, she is also enshrined at Inari-sha shrines in lieu of Ukanomitama since she was confused in later years with Inari-shin (a deity of harvest), who is also a deity of grain.

sen.j: 殺害された者の屍体の各部から栽培植物、とくに球根類が生じるという説話は、東南アジアから大洋州・中南米・アフリカに広く分布している。
sen.e: Anecdotes saying that domesticated plants, especially root vegetables, were born from a body of murdered person are widely distributed from South-East Asia, Oceania, Middle and South America to Africa.
